description:
Glossina pallidipes, commonly known as the Pale Tsetse Fly, is a species of tsetse fly that belongs to the genus Glossina. Tsetse flies are blood-feeding insects found in various parts of Africa, where they play a significant role in the transmission of several diseases, including human African trypanosomiasis (also known as sleeping sickness) and animal African trypanosomiasis (also known as nagana).

Glossina pallidipes is primarily found in eastern and southern Africa, with its distribution ranging from Ethiopia and Somalia in the north to South Africa in the south. It is a medium-sized tsetse fly, with a body length typically between 8 and 11 millimeters. The species is characterized by its pale coloration, with a yellowish-gray or pale brown appearance, which distinguishes it from some of the other tsetse fly species.

Glossina pallidipes is an important vector for the transmission of the parasitic protozoan Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense, which causes the Rhodesian form of human African trypanosomiasis. It is also known to transmit Trypanosoma congolense and Trypanosoma vivax, which are responsible for animal African trypanosomiasis in livestock, causing significant economic losses in affected regions.

The biology and behavior of Glossina pallidipes, such as its feeding habits, reproductive strategies, and environmental preferences, have been extensively studied to understand its role in the epidemiology of the diseases it transmits and to develop effective control measures.
